I'd also like to endorse Jeff Clune et al.'s EndlessForms site.  It is de=
finitely worth the trip.  It is clear from Picbreeder that the more people =
that participate in a site like these, the more impressive the evolutionary=
 creations become.  It will certainly be interesting to see what kinds of 3=
D objects evolve if enough people end up participating.  The idea of having=
 your evolutionary artifact printed in 3D and shipped is also a very novel =
prospect!  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> w=
rote:
>
> Hello all-
> 
> I am happy to announce a website where you can in=
teractively evolve 3D
> objects with CPPNs (the encoding for HyperNEAT):
> =

> http://www.EndlessForms.com <http://www.EndlessForms.com>
> 
> Please tr=
y the site out and publish the interesting objects that you
> discover. Doi=
ng so will help bolster the argument that CPPNs and other
> encodings based=
 on similar abstractions of developmental biology are a
> powerful way to e=
ncode phenotypes.
> 
> I have been amazed by the sorts of images Picbreeder=
 produced, but when I
> show the images to biologists and other scientists =
a frequent response is
> that they're "just" two-dimensional pictures and t=
hus don't show that CPPNs
> can produce interesting real-world (i.e. three-=
dimensional) forms. I never
> felt that way, but it got me wondering whethe=
r we could evolve equally
> compelling designs in three dimensions. To inve=
stigate that issue, a team of
> us here at Cornell built EndlessForms.com, =
which enables us as a community
> to explore the three-dimensional forms/ob=
jects/morphologies that CPPNs can
> produce. 
> 
> Evolving objects on the =
site is also an intuitive way to understand how
> mutation and crossover af=
fect CPPN phenotypes.
> 
> The site also demonstrates how 3D objects can be=
 automatically designed
> without a knowledge of 3D-CAD software. That's es=
pecially useful now that 3D
> printers are coming of age. We will soon add =
the ability to have any object
> on the site 3D-printed in a variety of mat=
erials (e.g. silver, steel,
> ceramic, etc.) and shipped to you.
> 
> As yo=
u'll see, we are heavily inspired by Picbreeder and utilized many of
> its =
successful design choices. Thanks to the entire Picbreeder team for
> comin=
g up with so many great ideas and sharing them. Special thanks to Ken
> Sta=
nley and Jimmy Secretan for providing helpful suggestions for improving
> e=
arlier versions of EndlessForms. We are actively developing the site, so if=

> any of you have any feedback on how to improve it, please let me know.
>=
 
> Some of you may be interested in the technology behind the site. We uti=
lize
> new web standards, such as WebGL, that enable the rendering of 3D ob=
jects.
> These technologies are brand new, so EndlessForms.com would not ha=
ve been
> technologically possible as recently as a year ago. EndlessForms.=
com is, to
> our knowledge, one of the first sites on the internet that uti=
lizes WebGL in
> anything but a WebGL demo.
> 
> PS. Please help generate t=
raffic to the site by sharing it with your
> friends, posting it to Faceboo=
k, etc. The goal is to really see what CPPNs
> can do by having as many peo=
ple exploring the design space as possible!
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune=

> 
> Postdoctoral Fellow
> Hod Lipson's Creative Machines Laboratory
> Cor=
nell University
> jeffclune@... <jeffclune@...>
> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>
